The Wise Fresher Playlist

With October rearing it's wet and wintry head, it's time to once again welcome some new self-loathing blood into our uni.

Review: SBTRKT

Manchester's Warehouse Project has yet again assembled the most celebrated and new purveyors of electronic music for three months worth of top acts.

Review: Alt-J

I haven't seen such crazed adoration of a band since Mumford & Sons made a rare appearance in Belgium two years ago. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Jason Williamson)

Local Spotlight: The Marzec Group

It's rare for a band both as young and student orientated as The Marzec Group to be full of such a high level of talent. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: Kluens Photography)

The Original Freshers

Has Freshers week at York always been the same? Bella Foxwell talks to the trendsetting freshers of the 60s to find out.

The Pride of the North

For decades the North of England lagged behind in the bid for gay equality. Stefan Roberts and Tom Witherow finds out what's changed

My Daughter, The Terrorist

By James Bithell

The Sri Lankan civil war was notorious for the atrocities committed. Laura Hughes finds out why the war left some women without any choice but to sign up.

Do I even like this?

Seriously, were you actually blown away or were you just quite impressed by how cool it looked?

My Brother the Devil

Director of new urban drama, Sally El Hosaini, talks about her film for the 56th BFI London Film Festival

A Real Love Story

Camila Batmanghelidjh, Founder of the charity Kids Company, speaks about the role of neuropsychology in her work with victims of abuse and neglect

Best Book: Merivel, A Man Of His Time by Rose Tremain

As always with Tremain, her new book is masterfully written. Merivel is a triumph, says James Metcalf.

The Naked Truth

As the celebrations of revolutionary artist Gustav Klimt are in full swing, Femke Gow takes a look at why he has become one of the most adored rebels of our time. (Thumbnail credit Klimt's last studio in Feldmuhlgasse, Vienna)

Face the Term in Jacquard

Campus Style Icon

By James Bithell

For the start of term, we present to you, a gentleman...

Festival Spotlight: Damnation Festival

Voted for by fans as the 'Best UK Festival' in <a href="http://www.terrorizer.com/blog1.php" target="_blank">Terrorizer</a> magazine, Damnation has given the metal scene a new lease of screaming, growling and ultra-loud life. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Inaki Campos)

Hedda Gabler

A show that has left critics reeling, Hedda Gabler shocks and enthralls. (Thumbnail credit Hedda Gabler, played by Sheridan Smith)

Killing Them Softly

Ostensibly a gangster film, but one that subverts the tradition of glamourising the criminal lifestyle

POSH

Laura Wade's interpretation of Posh is masterful, encouraging us to interrogate the class consciousness that dominates our society, and the political institutions that underpin it.

Much Ado about Something

There was clearly more than aesthetics at work in relocating Shakespeare's work to Delhi, giving us a glimpse into the more ambivalent social and cultural issues at work, says Poppy Bullard.

Miriam Margolyes in Dickens' Women

Margoyles subtly creates an argument that Dickens writing is not irrelevant to our lives, but rather an epitomising crucible of life says Ben Cross. (Thumbnail credit Margoyles in Dickens' Women)
